comments.commentBody:
"The agency’s inquiry has focused on whether Google has manipulated its search results, making it less likely that competing companies or products appear at the top of a results page."

How is that different than Ford refusing to sell me a Toyota? Google is giving me information for free. Leave them alone!

This is what business schools use case studies to do. They use past examples in place of controlled experiments that are too big to run.

There are plenty of case studies done by serious people who publish on these questions. It is available.

What is missing is honesty. Politicians don't like the answers. More specifically, they start out with answers they like, and pay "think tanks" and purported policy people to support those ideas with dishonest "studies."
I wish it was more like the tooth fairy, as a child I could always count on her.

Funny how that map could just be indicating education levels (with a few exceptions) There really are two countries and this dichotomy will  be more marked if the Repugnicans grab the White House come November.
"We do laundry every day so that the kids can bring a no-waste lunch to school." Can you pls elaborate on what this means? I am curious...
Or you could conceivably run into problems because you're wearing a helmet on a playground (who knew): http://www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/prerel/prhtml99/99065.html

Mark:

I generally agree with your comments, but this information will be very helpful in making the case against the Citizens United ruling. It is possible that you can analyze the money and the ads shown on television and reasonably determine who is spending what and for whom.

The key is to hold the candidate responsible for all ads that support him regardless of who pays for them. The national press institutions a la The New York Times, Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, et al. can help the American voter with this effort by providing unbiased news reporting.

The New York Times and Washington Post seem to be putting in the hard work and difficult research to do such reporting. See WaPo article here: http://tinyurl.com/Romney-Hubbard-economics.

What value could you place in knowing what ads I might finance, other than that my name could then be associated with one or another political party?   One can detect the political leaning of advertisements by content.  It seems unreasonable to seek the names of all donors separate from the overlying PAC.  The only value I can imagine would be in political advertising to nullify effectiveness of political ads that you decry.

Well, Learner, if I know which political candidates you support and which political positions are supported by your PAC, then I can decide whether I want to spend my money supporting your political views. If I know that you are a media company and that you, for example, support candidates and politicains who are trying to limit transparency about who buys which political ads, that tells me a lot about your company. Although it appears that the proposed regulation will not tell me if you helped pay for an ad through a PAC - only which PAC paid for the ad.

When I as an individual send money to a political candidate, that candidate has to list me, by name, on its reports and I believe those reports are on the internet. Why should your company be any different? Why should your financial support of a political PAC be any different?

This is a generally good idea. However, it is more important to know who is putting money into the PACs than the details of the ad buys of the PACs. We see the ads, we know who bought them. What matters is who is paying for it, not how the prices break down. A PAC isn't who is paying for it, it is a shell to hide who is paying for it.

We need to see whose money is buying what, not the price they paid by ad.

I suspect this has to do with Google's attempts to circumvent Apple's protections of their clients software.  Google added cookies that circumvented the default behavior of Safari so they could track users of this software more effectively.  They essentially hacked software belonging to other people so they could make more money on their monopoly.  It is not having a monopoly that is the problem it is the abusing of the monopoly to gain access to additional markets.  When you have the dominate search engine and people can't count on keeping the privacy that they have asked for then you have a real problem.

Interesting that those kids felt that way about Ehrenreich's book. I took from it that she had a tremendous amount of respect for the people who worked those jobs. For their bosses, not so much.

But maybe I'm more privileged than I think I am, causing me to have a different perspective.

Recently i was chatting with someone who works as a language arts support teacher at a vocational high school. She was telling me how offended her students were by Barbara Ehrenreich's book "Nickel and Dimed," which is about (to summarize very cursorily) what it's like to work at hourly-rate no-skill jobs. The students felt the author had no respect for ordinary people working hard at "regular jobs," and that their parents, and they, were being insulted by the book.

I'd be careful about assuming what "the disadvantaged" want. It isn't always what those of us who are not in that boat think.

I think it might be interesting for parents to take a pair of kids to work -- maybe their own plus a volunteer. Or just mix it all up and assign the kids randomly. Imagine what an eye-opener it might be for the doctor's son to spend the day cleaning offices.

WE have historical examples to show how the economy behaves under austerity measures and when the government spends to keep it going.

We hav been regaled with how the U.S. is the land of opportunity, and true it was. But most of the immigrants in the 1800s came to work where government spending had created those opportunities. It was easier to start a business and to buy land of course. But that land was available because of the Louisiana purchase. Access to that land was made easier by the building of the transcontinental railroads which were financed by the government. The steel industry grew to be the worlds largest due to the needs of the railroads, which were instrumental in the growth of the large cities. Chicago was the railroad hub for instance. Cattle and grains from the west, coal and iron ore from Minnesota and Pennsylvania all contributed to the economic power of the U.S.

But we have seen what happens when industry does not conserve. They use up their resources and then complain about regulations. We have seen that the great depression ended with the full employment act of WWII. It was government investment in the space programs that gave us the computer and micro electronics industries. Even the aircraft industry got its start from government funding.

The conservatives are locked into the Austrian school of economic ideology. it has been tried previously and it did not work then, and as we can see in Europe, it is not working now.

There have been a number of interpretations of the actual subject of "The Second Coming", and since having grown up in Ireland and having had the great good fortune to know many of those who knew him well, I listened carefully; the most popular view in the discussions on this poem in the forties by his contemporaries, almost all of whom had been leading Nationalists during the Troubles, was that it was about the leaders of that movement specifically.

Yeats was Anglo Irish, and Protestant and had derided the Nationalist leaders until after many were executed by the British, when he then changed his view. Among the executed was Major John McBride, the husband of Maud Gonne Mc Bride, Yeats's would be lover. The poem was intensely personal to him, since it dealt with people he knew intimately, including the young son of Maud Gonne, Sean McBride, who like Yeats, would be awarded a Nobel Prize. Two out of the six Irish Nobel winners, closely linked.

His life, in turbulent times, was often more interesting than his many plays, books, and terrific poetry.

Finally, I remain convinced that it would be extremely difficult to remove the theme and the history of the poem from the struggle for Irish freedom and independence and the principle players whom he knew well, and transport its lesson intact to the subject of the US Presidential Election. Though it was a nice try and it remains one of my favorite poems. Thank you.

Bryan, you shortchange Yeats. This poem goes well beyond the Irish struggles, and overwhelms the reader in its relevance and universality.

His poetry may be "terrific" for you and I'm sure you have your favorites. But it's precisely the capacity to articulate the human condition, anywhere at any time, that gives Yeats's work a force far greater than "terrific."

@ Pauline

In no way did I shortchange Yeats; what I have emphasized is what his contemporaries, including members of my own family, considered the passionate theme of this work; he was speaking of people he had earlier derided on political, religious and class grounds, and as the struggle went on, he changed his view of people who are remembered fondly by many Irish, though not all, as being very special to him.

The poem is widely quoted in many contexts; what I emphasized was both Yeats attachment to it and the views of his contemporaries, including Maud Gonne at that time. The same could be applied to the verses surrounding A Terrible Beauty is Born. He loved controversy and lived at a time when his efforts to promote healing after the Civil War when serving as a Senator influenced the development of the ethos of what Ireland subsequently became as it cast off the bitterness of that dreadful experience.

He remains a lifelong hero to me. Describing his poetry as terrific is a complement; he loved words and used them, as his lexicon of English usage illustrated as he proudly incorporated ancient Irish language and sagas into his work. He changed throughout his life starting out as a proud Anglo Irishman and gradually evolving to show all the Irish how to live together, proud of their own traditions. And it worked.

The poem in question is an illustration of that journey.

"Especially in this election, with no particularly pressing social or cultural issue demanding the attention of voters,..." Ahem. America decided long ago that slavery was wrong, but today we have been sold down the river into indentured servitude to banks, brokers and corporations. I'd call that a particular issue. To give credit where it is due, Mr. Obama's administration did save my house, but I don't think insurance companies are really concerned about anything but profit, and one other small issue-- profit should never be allowed to deny the necessities of life by extortion. The biosphere, starving children in Africa, Americans going without healthcare and education, and monopolized media ownership all attest to corporate hegemony and irresponsibility that is an issue of critical and pressing importance for actual persons who, unlike corporations, are only mortal. Life should be priceless, not cheap. All these constitute "particularly pressing social or cultural issue(s)" for both parties. Note what Yeats said about the center:
"Turning and turning in the widening gyre
The falcon cannot hear the falconer;
Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;
Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,
The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity."-- Yeats

This goes right to the heart of so many of our internal conflicts - the dissonance between that which we really want to love, and the unease that shades into mistrust as it becomes more powerful, more ubiquitous, and more surgically exact.

Google is indeed a superior product; swift, efficient even in its early days, while poor lame Yahoo and other also-rans stumbled along. It seemed to miraculously fulfill all our dreams of what the Intenet could and should be. Its avowed principles and values were what we longed for.

And then it was everywhere: mail, mapping and directions, comprehensive photographs of our houses and of the Earth itself, and most unsettling, of an uncanny prescience and accuracy about *us*, individually, and in particular.

And then we grew uneasy. We have so often been betrayed in our trust of all our institutions, our learned professions, our towers of authority and structure.

We wanted so much to believe in Sergei and his pals, yet we have too often felt the brush of alien fingers in our pockets, been too easily raped and looted by virtual footpads, that even as our search results grew both fatter and more exacting in their knowledge of *our* tastes, our preferences, our particular natures, our love and desire were poisoned by the very excellence Google gave.

It will be interesting to see what the Government does or does not prove. We are all of us holding our breath and clutching our hopes: Sergei, say it ain't so.

Fundamental misunderstanding: pumping money into the hands of workers during this period is not inflationary. Lord, it should be, but it isn't. We have quite a bit of deflation still around, and no notable inflation yet. When inflation starts going up, that's the time to ease off.
Only the inflation fairy can save us now.

WHH

Those who are concerned about their privacy should:
- Encrypt their WiFi links using WiFi Protected Access or better;
- Encrypt their email using Pretty Good Privacy or the free GPG;
- Use anonymizing services such as TOR.
Nobody is forced to have a relationship with Google, and those who don't have relatively little to fear from it. Other search services are available: DuckDuckGo, Yahoo, and Bing are obvious and probably there are others.
If you don't do these things you have no right to complain about Google.

I don't think it is evidence of paranoia to observe that the National Security Agency's plan to capture, store, and analyze essentially all U. S. telecommunication traffic - both data and voice - makes Google appear pretty insignificant. Unlike Google, there will be no opt out possibility.

In Jerry Reese we trust!

2011: Prince Amukamara. 2012 is crucial.
2010: JPP. I was hoping the Giants would trade up for MLB Rolando McClain or RB C.J. Spiller. That's why I watch the games from my living room on Sundays.
2009: Hakeem Nicks. Not Megatron but a solid A-/B+ WR who blocks, plays smart and is a solid individual. Can anyone see this guy pulling a Santonio Holmes act? Ever?
2008: Kenny Phillips. What would teams like the Jets or Pats give for this guy? And one more year removed from the knee surgery bodes well for 2012.

Bottom line: After last offseason I have blind faith in Jerry Reese.

The rich want more tax cuts for themselves so they say more austerity for everyone else. The rich claim to be job creators. How about this? All the millionaires who hide their money in the Cayman Islands, like Mitt Romney does, take the millions they are hiding and use it to create jobs in the United States. What good, exactly, are all these millions doing hidden in the Cayman Islands? Most rich, like Mitt Romney, could still buy anything they want even if they paid more taxes or used their money to create jobs in the US instead of China. They have more money than they can use, and yet they want more. I mean, how many car elevators can a person like Romney have?

That's incorrect.

Government policies can most certainly be tested in a scientifically-controlled manner.

I'm not sure why you think it has to be about profit. They could use happiness, economic fairness, environmental quality, etc as outcomes measures.

I think it sounds like an idea worth trying.

Government makes HUGE profits. Except we call it something very differen.

If I could go to "work" everyday and do what what they do, with the benefits they have, I would definitely call that a PROFIT

As one commentator as already said, government is not a business. It does not make a profit, its job is to provide for the best environment for it citizens to live in peace and prosperity. However, business constantly pushes the envelope to see just how far it can go in the quest for profits.

That is part of the experimenting you are suggesting, and business keeps at it until the citizens get fed up with it and demand some regulations and controls. Then business complains about all the restriction. For example, the clean air rules. We would not need them if business had not put maximizing profits in place of the citizens health. Notice that they clamor for free enterprise, but they do not want the other side of free enterprise, a citizens right to sue them for polluting his air. So if we can not get compensation for them polluting our air space, we will regulate them.

If they build faulty products and then seek legal protections, then we will make regulations to hold them responsible. Business can not act with impunity and expect to get way with it forever. There comes a day of reckoning and then they complain.

Sorry Mr. Brooks, your concept of government is distorted. However you can volunteer to be one of the test dummies if you wish, and we will all bid you good luck.

Does ONTHEPILL (not the answer to 2-down) pass the breakfast table test, although including it when so many states are being sexist might not be wise. Being as anti-over-population as I am, I really did not need to see REPEOPLED, which sounds like human breeding.

Last but not least, HOW HAS 44 ACROSS NEVER BEEN USED?! It's a perfect thing to troll the comment box with if someone calls a puzzle a blowthrough, when we all know it never is.

Delightful and endearing, Professor Raffman. Some people are irrepressible fountains of all that is best in humanity. It is clearly in all our best interests to respect and encourage the previously discarded majority of us who happen to also be women. I trust that nothing will stop them from manifesting the qualities which drove them to tolerate us all in the future. Unsung heroines offer much to admire.

Unless Google also controls it's nearby competition known as Yahoo, I'm of the opinion that the FTC is put their focus in the wrong direction.

In the last year, Yahoo has become a search engine to fear. Yahoo account holders were allowed to comment on news articles compiled though multiple sources, and from it's beginning, the comments represented the very broad mix that would be expected from a wide open source.

This is not true anymore. Yahoo IT is the control which alters the view most commonly. Opinions most common are predetermined by elimination of disabling the user, to the intervention of Yahoo Techs inserting abusive comments toward any liberal or common sense input based on how that threatens the far right liberal view.

Google Search is my safety net from Yahoo. I do not experience PC fluctuation in keyboard/mouse function, over sized screen image preventing me from accessing page functions or delayed timing/slow/-fast typing issues, etc...

Cyber has a problem. Monopolizing invites a multitude of abuse. Regulation is as absent as the U.S. Government is.

I pay for internet service. I expect to receive it.

If austerity were harmful to the wealthy, it would not be in the public discourse. Policy is designed to insure the status quo and the status quo, is as it always has been, to insure and maintain the wealth of the rich without regard to everyone else.

The "austerity'" in times of depression is "self-defeatist."

What more do you want as evidence? UK, now in a double-dip recession, and the Dutch and others.

Should be s warning to US economists. but would it ?? NOT to Paul Ryan economists !!!

Thank you, Paul, for warning us......
